clean_story:
"Facts we trust. Biases hide in them. "

The phrase "obvious truth" assumes clarity—but even facts get twisted by how we see them.
Like a mirror reflecting only what’s in front of it, but angled just slightly wrong.

We rely on shortcuts to process information.
A doctor might diagnose a rare disease faster in a patient who looks like past cases—even if symptoms match something else.
A study in 1999 showed radiologists missed a gorilla-sized image in a lung scan because they focused on tiny nodules.
Our brains filter "obvious" details to fit expectations.

Numbers aren’t neutral either.
A 2017 experiment found people rated the same crime as more severe when told "10 out of 100" vs. "10%"—even though they’re identical.
Framing shapes truth.
Even science isn’t immune.
A 2015 analysis revealed that studies with "positive" results were 3x more likely to be published than null findings.
What’s "obvious" often means "what we already believe. "

The gaps between facts.
How memory rewrites history.
Why neutral data doesn’t exist.
